binding.name: note
binding.literal: The subject should be used for academies, colleges or universities which are not covered by 'art academy', 'lecture', 'student' or the architecture category 'school/university college'. It should also be used for scenes of university, college life not covered by 'lecture', 'scholar', etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the acrobat is a circus, the term 'circus' should also be entered as a Subject. If on horseback, the term 'equestrian' should also be entered as Subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use when the scene is known to have come from the Biblical text, following Christ's death. Where appropriate (ie. in most cases), double-key with 'saint/martyr'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes the 7 Acts of Mercy (Feeding the hungry, Giving the thirsty to drink, Sheltering strangers, Clothing the naked, Visiting the sick, Visiting or liberating the imprisoned, Burying the dead) and the Spiritual Acts of Mercy (Warning sinners, Informing the ignorant, Advising the vacillating, Consoling the sorrowful, Bearing injustice patiently, Forgiving injuries, Praying for the living and the dead).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used in the widest sense, following the OED definition: 'The science and art of cultivating the soil; including the allied pursuits of gathering in the crops and rearing live stock; tillage, husbandry, farming (in the widest sense).'

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is used for images of a subject under the guise of another, such as a personification or emblem representing a concept.
Unless the specific type of allegory is listed as one its Narrow Terms, enter the Subject allegory/personification together with another term, the subject of the allegory, such as 'agriculture'. Where appropriate, terms listed as Non-Preferred Terms should be entered as Associated Names.
N.B.
An additional Subject of deity should be entered for the Roman period for some personifications which were worshipped as deities, e.g. Spes, Fortuna, Salus, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here to cover various mythological battles involving Amazons and Greeks, sometimes including Greek mythological figures like Herakles and Theseus. Although the most extensive Amazonomachies are on sculptural friezes, they also feature on a variety of objects ranging from gems to sarcophagi. See also the Subject Amazon.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
This term covers all the Americas.
If a specific ethnic Name is available, this is entered in Ethnic Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Only used by Prints & Drawings for history up to 323 AD.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a figure with feet or legs in the form of serpents but has also been used to refer to certain giants of ancient mythology. If the term is specified as 'anguipede giant', the Subject term 'titan/giant' should also be entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for bear-baiting, bull-baiting, cock-fighting, dog-fighting and other sorts of animal fighting arranged for human entertainment.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for animals fighting without human intervention. N.B. Enter hunting rather than animal-fighting where appropriate, e.g. for hounds attacking a fox at the end of a hunt.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for all forms of animal housing (eg. aviary, kennel), apart from farm buildings. Stables are listed individually, unless they form part of a farm, in which case the term 'farm' should be used.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for cartoon characters, such as Mickey Mouse, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to anthropomorphic figures in Western art as a well as to a specific iconographic motif in Nasca art (AMB).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for animals portrayed as human beings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for views of ruins and objects surviving into modern times from the remote past when neither the place nor the type of object (e.g. 'temple' or 'vase') can be identified.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used for exacavations and archaeological work in progress. For general views of ancient sites, the place name is recorded under topography, and no Subject is necessarily entered. For views of archaeological sites where the emphasis is on a building or structure rather than a general view, the place name is recorded as topography and the Subject is the type of building (e.g. 'temple') if the representation is a good example. For views of unidentified archaeological artefacts, the term 'antiquities' is used.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include details of buildings such as windows, doors, door furniture, chimneys, chimney-piece, chimney-breast, mantelpiece, etc. Only use for elaborate examples.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The subject includes buildings and edifices of any kind, structures and encampments.
For interiors of any of the NTs, double-key the relevant term with 'interior'.
See also the Object name 'architectural drawing'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Arhat is a term originally used for the immediate disciples of the Buddha who were expected to very rapidly follow the Buddha into Nirvana, or the Void where there was, at last, no further need for re-incarnation as all karma had worked itself out. The status of the arhats declined somewhat in later Buddhism as they, of course, were mainly concerned with their own salvation, while Mahayana Buddhism laid greater emphasis on ensuring the salvation of other beings. There are many individually named arhats; arhat group paintings are a common subject, and there are portraits of identifiable individual ones as well. The Chinese term is lohan, and the Japanese term is rakan.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a maker of armour or weapons.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes scenes representing the formal education of artists.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for scenes of activity which are not covered by the NTs, e.g. for artist's assistants preparing materials, or for parodies such as animals painting, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for personifications of the Liberal Arts and other Arts and Sciences. For non-allegorical use of the terms, see Arts/Architecture and Science.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also narrower terms of ART and ARCHITECTURE.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used for all mythical or mythological figures or creatures in Asian mythology. One of its Narrow Terms is a Broad Term in its own right, Indian mythological figure/creature, the others are a list of simple terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For personifications of Astrology, the term 'arts and sciences' is used. See also 'myth/legend' and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here in its original sense as being a competitor in physical exercises including athletics, boxing, wrestling, etc. To retrieve images of an athlete in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' should be included in the search.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is for images of athletics and people running races, in a competitive or general context. If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For events which do not fall under 'ceremony' but are formal occasions such as meetings, councils, or interviews granted by royalty, the clergy, government, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also the Ethnic Name 'Indigenous Australian'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used when the bag is of significance in the image.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Eaters of bad dreams and nightmares in Japanese legend.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance (e.g. an attribute of a boddhisattva).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to sets of works that usually each consist of 10 paintings. These 'songs of the seasons' visualise the month and seasons of the year. The main theme represented is the visualisation of lovers; their love in union and in separation is represented as the different months of the year.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include bivouacs, encampments, etc. in a military context.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used when the basket or basketry are of significance in the image.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use the term when the emphasis is on the activity of bathing, rather than, e.g., a beach scene. This covers both bathing as washing and bathing for recreation.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include battlecruisers, frigates, destroyers etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: One of the elements of the ragamala system.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The imagined consort of Bhairava Raga, one of the elements of the Ragamala system.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: On the broadest level, this subject covers scenes from the Bible and pious images, which have their own Subject headings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Literally 'beautiful woman' in Japanese art, most commonly seen in ukiyo-e paintings and prints of courtesans, geisha or ordinary townswomen; occasionally for images of young male prostitutes.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to views seen from a height. See also PANORAMA.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The nationality (where known) should be entered as an additional Subject term, e.g. for black Americans. When searching for images of black people of any nationality, search also for subject 'African'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For scenes connected with the production and use of books and newspapers.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If there is an emphasis on prostitutes in the scene, the additional term 'courtesan/prostitute' is included in the Subject field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an ox or bull skull used as a decorative motif, possibly with amuletic or symbolic meaning.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Buddhist councils started to be held after the Parinirvana of the Buddha to preserve the Buddha's teachings and monastic rules.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a wheel or discus like symbol which is commonly used in Buddhist, Hindu and Jain iconography.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A world leader in ancient Indian lore. Enter the name of the caktavartin, if known, in Associated Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is also an object name. Double-key if relevant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'calligraphy' is also an Object Name, for works described as 'calligraphy', especially in the Asia and Middle East departments.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term refers to a particular type of diminutive human figure which appears in the 18thC in the fine and decorative arts. Although described as Callot figures, they differ substantially from the work of Jacques Callot.
See G. B. Bauer and H. Verfonern, 'Barocke Zwergenkarikaturen von Callot bis Chodowiecki', exhib. cat., Salzburg, Galerie der Stadt, 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double key with 'gambling' if necessary. Also use for designs for playing-cards (P&D only). Actual playing-cards should be entered as such in the object name field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to portraits. See also satire.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Used traditionally for the festival held immediately before Lent, particularly in Venice; often used in calendars to illustrate February

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used to describe fortified buildings, including feudal castles. Grand houses, such as French châteaux, are indexed as 'palace/mansion'. Where appropriate both terms may be used, e.g. for Windsor Castle or the Tower of London.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Theterm is also used for anti-catholic subjects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here to cover general battles between Centaurs and Greeks (usually Lapiths). See also the Subjects Centaur and Lapith.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for ceramics.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Department of Africa, Oceania and Americas collection.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'charioteer/chariot' is used for images of charioteers or chariots or both where the context is not chariot-racing (for which use the term 'charioteer/chariot-racing'). If the chariot is being driven by a deity, emperor, soldier, personification, etc. an additional Subject term should be entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Use this term for charioteers or chariots or both in a chariot-racing context, even if the race itself is not depicted, such as victors being crowned. See also 'prize-giving' and 'circus/hippodrome'.
For charioteers or chariots in other contexts, use 'charioteer/chariot'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had iconographic significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should not be used as a Subject in P&D.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In P&D, restricted to scenes representing childhood activities (apart from 'school' and 'sport/pastime' which should be used instead) and for child labour.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For works by artists when children.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A grotesque monster, formed of the parts of various animals.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use only for pious images, not in a biblical setting. Images of Christ may be found under the Narrow Terms of `Christ', `New Testament' or 'God Father'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use when Christ is shown with the Instruments of the Passion, not in a Biblical setting.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images, not in a biblical setting.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting. Do not confuse with 'Crucifixion'; see notes under 'Passion'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for systems of belief differing from the orthodox traditions; sometimes applied specifically to groups that are regarded as heretical.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use this term for cathedrals, chapels, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In Buddhist iconography, this is a flaming jewel which is supposed to grant all wishes to the wearer.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term applies to performances, and additional Subject terms such as ‘acrobat/street performer’, 'clown', ‘equestrian’, etc. should be added as necessary. The term should also be entered for views of travelling circuses, including tents and equipment.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The circus was a long rectangular structure where Roman chariot racing events took place. The hippodrome was a long rectangular area where in Greek times, chariot and horse races were staged, often with little if any architecture but sometimes with banks of earth for the spectators to stand on, and its use continued down into Roman times. Some well-known Roman examples include the Circus of Maxentius (Circus of Caracalla), the Circus Maximus and the Circus Flavinius.
See also the terms 'Roman amphitheatre/arena', 'classical theatre/odeon' and 'classical stadium'.
N.B.
The Stadium of Domitian, also known as the 'Circo Aragonale', and sometimes as the 'Circus of Domitian', was a stadium, not a circus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes town halls, etc. See also meeting space/ceremonial ground.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes examples of simulated classical costume.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Certain figures in classical mythology, e.g. Herakles (Hercules), are considered as both a classical deity and classical mythological figure and these two Subjects should be entered in such cases.
The 'classical deity' includes syncretic deities combining attributes of classical and non-classical deities.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
In some cases a Narrow Term of 'classical mythological figure' is also the name of an individual, recorded in the Associated Name field. Examples include: sibyl and Cumean Sibyl', 'triton and 'Triton', 'amazon' and 'Amazon', etc.
Certain figures in classical mythology, e.g. Herakles (Hercules), are considered as both a classical deity and classical mythological figure and these two Subjects should be entered in such cases.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term classical mythology is used for scenes of classical mythology. If the main subject of the image is a classical deity, mythological figure or mythical creature, the Subjects 'classical deity' or 'classical mythological figure/creature' (or its Narrow Terms) are used instead of 'classical mythology', and their individual names, when known, are entered in Associated Name.
N.B.
Some named mythological figures or creatures (Biographical Authority entries and Associated Name field) have become generic terms (Subject field) as well, e.g. Nereid, Triton, and a nereid or triton, etc. If those named individuals are recorded in Associated Name, the Subject term equivalent has to be entered as well, but not vice-versa.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term encompasses the athletic contests, exercise and spectacles which took place in the Greek and Roman world. Before such events became part of major games festivals and entertainment, they were often part of funeral rituals, with the contests originally held to decide who should inherit the possessions of the deceased. A variety of events, many of which are not exclusive to the Classical World, were involved. In addition to the five major games festivals held at Olympia, Delphi, Nemea, Corinth and the Isthmus, there were hundreds of minor sports festivals. All tended to have the same core events: running, the pentathlon (running, discus, javelin, long jump, wrestling), combat events (boxing, wrestling, the pankration) and equestrian events (chariot and bare-back racing), with a variety of additions. From the surviving depictions we cannot know whether a particular festival is being represented, but because the core events were common to nearly all the games we can use them as generic representations of these sports. For example, no depictions survive that we can directly associate with the ancient Olympics but athletic and equestrian scenes on vases, the bulk of which were produced in Athens, can nonetheless be used to illustrate the type of events that were staged at the Olympics. By Roman times sports contests, especially gladiatorial combat and chariot racing, were increasingly employed as entertainment. See ‘amphitheatre/arena’, ‘palaistra/gymnasium’, ‘stadium’.
If a sport is depicted in the context of classical sport, but the Subject term for it is not included as a Narrow Term here (e.g. athletics), the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is added.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term applies to a Greek or Roman long, rectangular structure, sometimes with banks or seats for viewing, purpose-built for athletic contests. .See also the term 'circus/hippodrome'.
N.B.
The Stadium of Domitian, also known as the 'Circo Aragonale', and sometimes as the 'Circus of Domitian', was a stadium, not a circus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
In Greek and Roman cultures, a theatre was a building purpose-built for housing dramatic performances and contests, whereas an odeon was a roofed building used for musical performances. Some well-known examples of theatres include those at Ephesus, Epidaurus, Herculaneum, Jerash, Miletus, Rome (Theatre of Marcellus), Pompeii (the 'Great' or 'large' theatre), Syracuse, Taormina. The Odeon at Pompeii is sometimes referred to as the 'small theatre’ or occasionally as the ‘covered theatre'.
See also the term 'Roman amphitheatre/arena'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes priests, vicars, cardinals, bishops, rabbis, mullas, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the clown is in a circus, the term 'circus' should also be entered as a Subject. If on horseback, the term 'equestrian' should also be entered as Subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for depictions of collages or works in mixed media, not for the objects themselves.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Artists' colourman: dealer in artists' materials

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should also be used for recitals, including informal events performed in a domestic setting..

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double-key with whatever is being built. Use also for repair and rebuilding of architecture or structures such as bridges.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used when the container is of significance in the image.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term includes any form of of make-up and also patches used in the 17thC and 18thC in Europe as a fashionable ornament for faces.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double-key with other terms in the thesaurus as necessary, e.g. 'baker'. See also Object Name 'costume print' and Subject 'personal ornament'. This category and its NTs should be used very sparingly, for very detailed examples of costume.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the image includes a brothel or brothel-keeper, the additional term 'brothel/brothel-keeper' is included in the Subject field. See also 'kamuro'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This subject is very broad and covers all aspects of romantic love, courtship, elopement, etc. See also the Subject terms: marriage/wedding', 'married life', and 'eroticism/pornography'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also 'metalworker'. The term 'jeweller' is s search term for 'craftsman/maker' rather than 'metalworker' as not all jewellery is made of metal.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Do not confuse with 'Christ on Cross'. See note under `Passion'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a place where milk and cream are kept, and made into butter and cheese, and also includes the use of the term to designate a shop in which milk, cream, etc. are sold.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the production of milk, butter and cheese. For representations of dairy buildings, the term 'dairy' should be used. When the emphasis is on people milking, the the combined term 'milkmaid/dairyman' should be used for European scenes, and 'herder' for non-European scenes.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Only use the actual term 'Death' for memento mori, death-bed scenes, death-masks, and any allegorical representations such as the Dance of Death, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The final transition of Sakyamuni to the enlightened state. Iconographically represented by the buddha lying on his side, surrounded by his followers, including Ananda. Before he abandoned his body to the deathless state of nirvana, he told his followers not to keep relics. And so the body was cremated. However, relics were retained and placed in stupas.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the main Subject is a classical deity the Subject term deity is used instead of classical mythology, and the individual name is entered in Associated Name. See also classical mythology.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double-key with whatever is being demolished.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A guardian of a specific direction (North, North-East, etc.) in Hindu and Buddhist art.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This does not refer to the Twelve disciples of Christ, but rather to the more general use of the term.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered. See also the term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms refer to large enclosures, adjoining the sea or a river, in which ships are built or repaired. (OED).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is for family scenes and scenes in a home setting, e.g. people engaged in domestic activities and chores. See also servant/domestic worker.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for amateur as well as professional artists.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to recreational drugs. For the medical context, see 'medicine'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Very important in mainland Southeast Asia for horoscopes, etc. Each day of the week is assigned an animal, Wednesday is divided in two.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: These include: artemesia leaf, rhinoceros horns, books, stone chime, mirror, lozenge, golden coin and dragon pearl.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: These include: endless knot, wheel of the Law, conch shell, parasol, canopy, lotus, lidded jar and paired fish. This term should be entered in all cases where all, of only some, of the items listed here occur in this context. In the case of lotus, (paired) fish, enter these terms as well.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here in the sense of a tribal elder, and not in the sense of a Christian minister (or any other use of the term).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use when the emphasis is on the individual, not the scene. This term should not be used in P&D records.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Sakyamundi's father did everything he could to protect his son and to ensure that he would become a great king. A great wall was built around the palace, and all negative influences were kept away from the young prince. The prince was happy and successful. He married and had a child. However, one day he decided to leave the palace to see his people. During this visit he encountered old age, sickness and death for the first time. He was profoundly moved, and the compassion within him led him to want to bring an end to the suffering.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use this term when the subject is not covered by the narrow or related terms, e.g.: for horseman hacking, in dressage, or in a more general context.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should be used for all subjects connected with consenting sex or lasciviousness. See also molestation/assault.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
This subject covers village or country fairs and fêtes as well as funfairs. It should also be used for the rides or structures present at such events, or in public playgrounds, such as merry-go-rounds, etc.
See also the Subject 'fête champêtre'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Subject covers people owning and working on their farms, and those employed to work on farms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for farming scenes, with emphasis on the activity. See also: 'farmer' and 'farm building/farmyard'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for street brawls, domestic violence, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: P&D: restrict, in the main, to artists by whom the Department has a lot of drawings and who are better known for another type of work. Use sparingly for exceptional examples by other artists.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For temporary architecture erected for firework displays, see 'temporary architecture'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Sakyamuni gave his first sermon in the deer park of Benares. Iconographically, this event is often depicted as two deer, one on either side of a wheel. The wheel represents both the dharma that is teaching and the cosmos, the Buddha being both the universal cosmic monarch and the teacher of the path to enlightenment.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for all types of fishing including whaling, whether sporting, commercial or subsistence.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for images of drying, smoking, pickling food for storage etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'clown ' is used for circus clowns.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to Japanese iconography, where it has the specific meaning of imagery relating to foreigners associated with the ports of Nagasaki and Yokohama, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Restricted to detailed examples or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for furniture or woodwork.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Fuzoku is a Japanese term for 'genre scenes'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Fête champêtre is a term used to describe the depiction of figures enjoying pleasures in an open-air setting. The theme can first be identified in 16th-century Italian art, notably in Venice in the paintings of Giorgione and Titian, although the term fête champêtre was not applied at the time. Its development can be traced through to the 18th century when a variant, known as the fête galante, practised principally by French artists (notably Antoine Watteau, Nicolas Lancret and Jean-Baptiste Pater), gained popularity as a genre. Subsequently, from the early 19th century the term fête champêtre was increasingly applied to the earlier Italian works and to the theme as a whole.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include gambling, betting, wagering. Double-key with card-playing, etc., as necessary. For prizes awarded in contests, see 'prize-giving'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should be used for noteworthy individual items of clothing. See also ceremonial dress and other subcategories of costume/clothing.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for community and formal gatherings - do not use for small gatherings, such as family meals.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to people of unusually large or small size; for mythical beings, see 'titan/giant' and 'ogre/giant'. For any named giant, enter the name in Associated Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here to refer to the general battle between the Olympian gods and the Titans (often referred to as Giants). See also Subjects deity and Titan.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used in preference to 'gladiator' when a combat is shown.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for glass.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: god the father and the holy spirit

binding.name: label
binding.literal: god the father with christ and saints

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use in JA only, for detailed depictions.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Buddha decided to renounce his life in the palace and become and ascetic in the hope of ending suffering. One night he quietly left the palace, leaving his parents, wife, and child. He took his white horse, and it is said that the four heavenly kings held the four hooves of his horse so that they would not make noise and wake the palace guards.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to particular type of Parisian working woman in the eighteenth century..

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to a figure in Asian religious art.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms 'gymnasium' and 'palaistra' refer to facilities where exercise and athletic competitions took place in classical times. Combat events such as boxing and wrestling were a speciality of the Greek 'palaistra', whereas the Roman 'palaestra' was an exercise area attached to public baths.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If an interior is shown double-key with INTERIOR.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This Subject should only be used when the emphasis of the image is on the objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a fabulous monster with a woman's face and body, and a bird's wings and claws.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes wigs. Double-key as necessary with specific costume.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Also enter Hades or Hell in Associated Place.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for illustrations of the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Life of Kṛṣṇa, Jaimini Bharata, Markandeya Purana, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The hintha bird is a Burmese version of the ancient Indian hamsa bird. In both contexts, it is associated with royalty. The hintha bird is the symbol of the city of Pegu.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For P&D, do not use this term in the Subject field; use its narrow terms, or for historical events after 1453, the Historical Event field. See also the satire category for satirical drawings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for scenes with the three figures of Mary, Joseph, and Christ Child only, and where not in a biblical setting. See also note under `Nativity'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: holy family with god the father

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting. See also note under `Nativity'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Only to be used in connection with our lady of loreto

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for images of actual human remains rather than the Nasca 'trophy head' motif, or allegorical or satirical images of human remains.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double-key with subject of the humour.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for all types of hunting and shooting, whether sporting, commercial or subsistence.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is for recording examples of huts in non-western contexts, often used as dwellings or as meeting-places, or having another social significance. It is not intended for beach-huts, outbuildings, etc.
In many instances, it is not possible to determine the intended use of a hut or thatched building, ie. whether domestic or not. Anyone interested in representations of domestic buildings should therefore also include this category in their searches.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Other terms, such as 'ceremony/procession', 'festival', etc., should be added as additional Subject terms as necessary. The term itself should not be used in P&D.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A mint is both the institution responsible for making coins and the industrial building where the processes happen. As most of the buildings reresented are for the industrial buildings, 'mint' is a Non-Preferred Term for 'industrial building'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Subject term recording the type of building is added in addition to the term 'interior' (e.g.: 'civic building').

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'personal ornament' is often used in preference to 'jewellery' in non-European contexts. Searches on the Broader Term 'personal ornament' will provide the broadest results.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for images characterising Jewish people, rather than for every image of someone who happens to be Jewish; see also judaism and anti-semitism. For images of rabbis, see 'cleric'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for Jewish religious subjects; see also Jewish and anti-semitism. For images of rabbis, see 'cleric'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include judgement by priest, Herod, or Pilate.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The eighteen favourite roles of the kabuki actor Ichikawa Danjuro.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For scenes from plays; use 'theatre/opera house' for the buildings. Double-key with 'actor' and enter other actors' names, play details, etc. in the Associated fields as necessary.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A kamuro is a child attendant to a courtesan in Japan. See also 'courtesan'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to half human, half bird creatures (kinnara - male; kinnari - female) known for their faithfulness to their spouse.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Although some images of kitchens do not relate to interiors, the term 'kitchen' is under the Broad term 'interior' as that is the context in most instances.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Furisode are extra wide sleeves on young women's kimono, indicative of unmarried status. Conversely, kosode are narrow sleeves on women's kimono, indicative of married status.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the divine play (lila) of the god Kṛṣṇa.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Japanese thirty one syllable comic poem, known as 'crazy' or 'mad' verse.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should be used for manual workers, other than agricultural workers. See also 'agricultural worker' and its Narrow Terms and other Narrow Terms of 'trade/occupation'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Do not confuse with `Pieta'. See note under Passion.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use the subject term when the emphasis is on the depiction of the object.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For JA, LANDSCAPE includes coastal views. P&D: restrict this term, in the main, to artists by whom the Department has a lot of drawings or prints and who are better known for another type of work. Use sparingly for exceptional examples by other artists.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For the interior, the term 'law-court' is used.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for any kind of library. If the library is building attached to a school, university or college, the additional term 'school/university/college building' should also be entered as a Subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To exclude any scenes involving Christ.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For scenes with lifeboats in action.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the aniconic form of the god Siva, depicted as a standing phallic column. It is also an Object Name for sculptures in the shape of a linga. The Associated Name Śiva should also be entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A guardian of one of the Four Quarters of Space in Hindu and Buddhist iconography.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The throne, pedestal or seat in which the Buddha is often represented seated.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for allegorical representations of Love.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Syllables believed to have special religious and protective power.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is a traditional Japanese motif, based on a poem.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include domestic marital scenes, also cuckoldry, divorce, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'mask' is to be used for noteworthy depictions of any type of mask, apart from theatrical masks, which have their own entry..

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also the Subject 'Massacre of the Innocents'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Shaman is a Siberian term from the Evenk, used and misused extensively in North America and elsewhere in the world as a concrete category.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This category includes 'alternative' medicine and treatments.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Prints & Drawings only. For history between 323 AD and 1453.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
A meeting space, at which religious ceremonies and/or social functions are carried out. In Polynesia the space incorporates built structures (whether building or stepped platforms) as well as exterior space, usually delineated by a boundary wall or fence.
See also civic building.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for metalwork.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to most types of metalworkers, but there are separate entries for 'armourer', 'blacksmith/farrier' and 'goldsmith/jeweller' which are Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms refers to people milking, working in dairies or otherwise involved in selling dairy produce. For non-European contexts, use herdsman if appropriate.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers here to images of people engaged in coin production, including engravers, assayers, people strking coins, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a representation in Japanese art in which two normally unconnected phenomena are playfully linked. Sometimes translated as 'parody'. Yatsushi is a related, but narrower term, which specifically refers to cases in which scenes from the past are impersonated in modern dress.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is for modern stadia and arena, often for not exclusively in the context of sporting events. See also 'classical stadium'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For depictions of misers, see the Description field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The additional subject 'sculpture' should be added as necessary.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use more specific terms where possible.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also 'astrology' and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Cobra (Sanskrit). In Indian iconography, there is a group of minor deities who have a snake form. The king of the snake deities is nagaraja, female snake deities are nagini, the snake festival is Nagapancami. In Buddhist mythology, there are several named nagas, one of whom is the nagaraja Apalala, another is Mucalinda.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Nats are spirits in the Burmese belief system the need to be propitiated so that they do not cause harm. Some nats occupy natural features, such as trees and bodies of water, and others are part of a more formal system called the Thirty-seven Lords. The latter are named individuals who died violent (‘green’) deaths, and around whom a whole mythology has developed. In addition to small offerings, the nats are also celebrated in periodic festivals called ‘nat pwe’ where mediums are possessed by the spirits. Belief in nats probably pre-dates the arrival of Buddhism in Burma during the first millennium of the common era.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Narrow Terms of this Subject are used for images that comment on, rather than merely represent, national or cultural characteristics. See also the Subject costume/clothing and its Narrow Terms and the Ethnic Name field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the specific Ethnic Name is available, it is entered in that field. See also 'Native North American' and its Narrow Terms in Ethnic Name for drawings, paintings and photographs of portraits in the Department of AOA representing Native North American people.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Certain representations which are pious images, not portrayed in a Biblical setting, should not be keyed under `Nativity' but rather under the relevant narrow term of the 'Christ' category. An example is `Holy Family' (narrow term of `Christ') versus `Nativity' (narrow term of `Birth of Christ').

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Naumachia is the term (originally Greek) for a sea battle, but became used also for the purpose built venues for such battles.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an astrological theme in South and Southeast Asia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See categories 'Christ' and 'Virgin' for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For specific examples other than those listed as narrower terms, use 'non-conformist'. The term should also be used for scenes of non-conformist activity, and should be double-keyed with the 'preacher/evangelist' term when a preacher is non-conformist.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The subject is restricted to creatures of folklore and myth; the Subject 'titan/giant' is used for classical giants. For any named giant, the name is entered in Associated Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Records must have Fatima in Associated place as well as Virgin in Associated Name. Subject blank.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Nossa Senhora da Conceicao da Praia.
Problem - leave

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of good counsel of praia

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of san juan de los lagos

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The alternative name used in inscriptions is "SCEX".

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Originally associated with St Francis of Assisi and the chapel of Our Lady of the Angels in Poriuncula (near Assisi, Italy).

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the blessed scapular

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the morning star

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the pine tree

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the rosary of fatima

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the rosary of pompei

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the sacred heart

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady of the seven sorrows

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Miraculous icon at the Chiesa Nuova in Rome for which Rubens designed an altarpiece.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Associated with Notre Dame des Vertus at Aubervilliers (Seine).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Shrine of the Mystery of the Incarnation; also referred to as Heavenly Empress.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: our lady star of the sea

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for external (e.g. house painters) and internal decorators.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for grand houses. Where these are fortified, e.g. Windsor Castle, the term castle/fort may also be used.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to designs for 19thC 360º panorama, or drawings connected with them.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: parable of wise and foolish virgins

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In Asia, where it represents several paradises associated with different buddhas.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Certain representations, which are pious images, not portrayed in a Biblical setting, should not be keyed under a narrow term of `Passion', but rather under a narrow term of the `Christ' category. An example is `Christ on Cross' (narrow term of `Christ') versus `Crucifixion' (narrow term of `Passion').

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is used for scenes with country people, other than specifically agricultural subjects for which other Subjects are used (e.g. 'ploughing').
Tavern scenes, markets and festivals are entered as additional Subjects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Also known as Pall-Mall. Game with a ball and mallet played in an alley.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs, for fans, etc. See also Object Name field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term 'personal ornament' is often used in preference to 'jewellery' in non-European contexts. Searches on the Broader Term 'personal ornament' will provide the broadest results.
See also 'personal ornament'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Simurgh' is the Persian term for a type of phoenix.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should only be used for unusual physical conditions, e.g. conjoined twins or extremely tall, small, obese, etc. people. Such people were exhibited in fairs, etc. until the early 20thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for images of the Dead Christ with Mary, when a pious image, not in a Biblical setting.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In Europe, the term refers to gardens created as commercial resorts for city-dwellers, of the type popular from the 17th to the middle of the 19th century, e.g. Vauxhall Gardens in London, Tivoli in Copenhagen.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Pleasure quarters refer to areas with brothels, tea houses and theatres, ie. general entertainment areas.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, in this case political. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term includes all members of national and local government.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also satire category for satirical drawings and prints.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A female priest of a non-Christian religion.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should not be used in P&D records.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term covers the production of both prints and printed text.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the representation of the act of prize-giving, or of an actual prize awarded, in several contexts, but more usually that of rewarding victors in athletic and other types of contests. In the Classical World, woollen fillets and wreaths were often used to denote victory; these are included within the term as well as the giving of valuable objects such as metal vessels. The term 'classical games' or 'education' etc. should also be used to indicate the context where appropriate. For lottery prizes, see 'gambling/gaming'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, usually political or religious. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for works illustrating popular wisdom, proverbs, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This covers all forms of punishment, such as pillory, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Before the Buddha was born, the Queen his mother dreamed of a white elephant. This dream heralded the birth of either a great king or a wise and pure sage.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Ragamala are paintings inspired by raga (Indian music), ragini are a modification of a raga.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use the terms 'baptism', 'marriage', etc., for religious ceremonies, rather than religion.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To include tripods, mitres, etc. See also cross (under symbol).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, in this case religious. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

binding.name: label
binding.literal: restoring the blind man to sight

binding.name: label
binding.literal: return of the holy family from egypt

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Roman amphitheatres (also called arenas) were ovoid structures used for entertainment and spectacles, including gladiatorial and animal combats and mock battles. The best-known examples include the amphitheatres in: Arles, Bosra, Beneventum, Bordeaux, Capua, El Djem, Leptis Magna, Nîmes, Pozzuoli, Pula; Rome (Colosseum), Trier, Verona.
See also the term 'classical theatre/odeon'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Remember also to enter named boat races, e.g. Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race, in As.Event.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Neither this term, nor its Narrow Terms, should be used in P&D.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To cover all naval ranks, e.g. admirals, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For images of saints and martyrs, and scenes from their lives, when not covered by the New Testament or 'Christ' categories. Only in the case of `Acts of Apostles' should the term 'saint/martyr' be double-keyed when relevant (i.e. in most cases).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should not be used in P&D.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for any satirical subject. N.B. for P&D, enter the subject 'satire' for ANY print which is satirical, even if it duplicates the object name 'satirical print'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: According to the OED, a faun is god or demigod worshipped by shepherds and farmers, and identified with the Greek Pan wheraes a satyr is a woodland god or demon, partly human and partly animal, supposed to be the companions of Bacchus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for scenes of teaching. Do not use for riding schools (where horses and riders are being schooled); for this use equestrian. See also school/university/college for architecture.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for views of school, university, college, etc. buildings. Do not use for riding schools (where horses and riders are being schooled); for this use equestrian. See also school for scenes of education.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use this term for sea animals which are not covered by the main categories of animals listed.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for representations of the seasons (see 'Time/Seasons' for allegorical representations).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Do not use this term for depictions of non-mythical snakes, use 'reptile' instead.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should only be used if it has also been entered as an object name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The name 'asssociated Name 'Cumaean Sibyl' should also be entere in the Associated Name field, where appropriate.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is used for a representation of an encounter or fight between two combatants, usually armed, in a military context. If the single combat occurs as part of a battle scene, the term 'battle' is used instead (or as an additional Subject) depending on the emphasis of the representation. See also the Subject 'duel'.
For gladiatorial combats use that term instead.of 'single combat'.
In the case of Amazonomachy, Gigantomachy or Centauromachy use those terms instead of 'single combat' in all cases.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Enchantresses or sea nymphs, commonly two or three in number, and often represented as birds with women's heads; their fantastic songs caused those seafarers who heard them to become mad or to land and be devoured.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is for smoking tobacco, opium or other substances.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Subject term 'soldier' is entered for images of sentinels, even though they are not always military.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is used for illustrations of the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Life of Kṛṣṇa, Jaimini Bharata, Markandeya Purana, etc.
'Ramayana' and 'Mahabharata' are entered in Associated Title.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: south and south east asian myth/legend

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is under three Broad Terms as the activity can occur in different contexts, professional or leisure.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also hunting/shooting and fisherman/fishing, as these subjects include hunting and fishing in sporting and non-sporting contexts.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the stable is part of a farm, use 'farm'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should not be used for Prints & Drawings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The specific trade or occupation should also be entered as a Subject, if known, and if listed as a Narrow Term of TRADE/OCCUPATION.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term applies to any student. For an art-student at an academy, use 'art academy' an an additional subject, for other art-students, use 'artistic life' as the additional term.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Swastika (Sanskrit svástika) is an ancient symbol of good luck used by many cultures from c. 3000 BC onwards. It remains widely used in India and as a religious symbol in Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism. In the West, the symbol is stigmatised by its iconic association with Nazi Germany.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use when the emphasis is on the activity of swimming, rather than, eg.: a beach scene.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should also be used also for Renaissance imprese and similar subjects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A convivial meeting for drinking, music, and intellectual discussion among the ancient Greeks or Romans.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A subject which refers to ideas expounded in the Indian texts known as the Tantras. These ideas often equate microcosm with macrocosm, and sexual with cosmic.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Includes catafalques, triumphal entry constructions, settings for fireworks displays, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Whilst Sakyamundi was meditating under the Bodhi tree, Mara, the Evil One, tried to prevent the boddhisattva from gaining enlightenment. First he sent his three daughters to try and seduce and distract Sakyamundi. He was not distracted. As they approached him, they aged and withered, which angered their father greatly. After this insult, Mara send his hoards against the meditating sage. However, all the weapons that were directed at him turned to harmless flowers.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'encampment' in this non-military context is defined as the temporary quarters, formed by tents, vehicles, etc., occupied by a body of nomads or men on the march, travellers, etc. or a lodging in tents, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Examples include the Edda, the Nibelungen legend and the gods of Norse mythology.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for detailed examples, or designs. Use appropriate related term for the manufacture of textiles, and 'costume' where relevant. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for textiles.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Buddha met the ascetics in the forests and trained with them for many years before he learned that true enlightenment comes from the middle way.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Buddha was born on the roadside beneath a sala tree. The Queen stood beneath a tree holding the branches above her head, and the baby was born from her left side. The baby could walk straight away, and with each step a lotus appeared beneath his foot.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the buildings; see also theatre/theatrical life, and classical theatre/odeon for classical buildings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for performance and other aspects of theatrical life. For buildings, use theatre/opera house and for classical theatres, use 'classical theatre/odeon'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for allegorical representations of the seasons, months, day and night, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is used for giants and titans in classical mythology. The name 'Titan' or a more specific name is entered in Associated Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the emphasis is on an activity or occupation, additional Subject terms should be entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term should not be used for Prints & Drawings.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Trade and industry are defined very broadly here. For example, some of the Narrow Terms (e.g. 'sewing') are examples of trades in the sense of skilled handicrafts.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
This category covers cestablished trades and occupations as well as covering different 'types' in society such as 'grisette' or 'dandy' and people adopting or assuming a mode of life such as 'ascetic'.
The Narrow terms are used when the emphasis is on the individual, not on the related activity, e.g.: a representation of an actor, rather than a play (which would go under 'theatre' instead). If the person depicted is also a street-trader, enter this term as a Subject as well. N.B. For Prints and Drawings: in the case of named portraits, the trade/occupation of the sitter is not entered in Subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Double-key with relevant category of nationality/date costume.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used mainly for people bearing tribute, but not in a biblical context. See also 'tribute money' for the Biblical subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the mythological individual Triton is represented, not just a 'triton', also enter Triton in Associated Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a motif widely used in pre-Columbian art.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In mediaeval Arabic and Ottoman Turkish orthography the tughra is a calligraphic emblem of Turkish rulers, from the time of the chiefs of the Oghuz to the Seljuqs and succeeding rulers in Persia, the Mamluks and the Ottoman sultans. In Ottoman practice it became in effect the emblem of the state.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term includes tunnels carved into rockfaces.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A perspective picture particularly relating to townscapes or building interiors. This term must be entered both as Object Name and Subject.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Buddha sat beneath the Bodhi tree, a banyan or pipal tree, meditated and gained enlightenment. In some depictions a Naga rises up behind him to protect him.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A thunderbolt symbol in Buddhist iconography.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The last of the ten great Jataka stories (Sakyamuni Buddha's previous lives) that is associated with the virtue of generosity.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For images with only the Virgin and Child, no other biblical figures present. See also Holy family, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for pious images. Do not use for scenes from the life of the Virgin which are covered by New Testament categories, such as VISITATION or NATIVITY, for example.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
These are generally: the three Theological Virtues (Faith, Hope and Charity) and the four Cardinal Virtues (Prudence, Temperance, Fortitude and Justice) and the seven Vices/Sins (Pride, Envy, Sloth, Anger, Covetousness, Gluttony and Lust) although they vary.
For depictions of misers, see the Description field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For all the stages of wine production.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Japanese thirty one syllable classical or classical style poem.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for professional washerwomen and washermen as well as for others washing clothes, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the subject is a water-seller, that term is used instead of water-carrier.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for scenes with people drawing water from wells, rivers, etc. and carrying it.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is under three Broad Terms as the activity can occur in different contexts, professional or leisure.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Mythical figures said to inhabit the forests of Central Europe, often represented on coats-of-arms. Double-key with 'heraldry' as necessary.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance (e.g. an attribute of a boddhisattva).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For feminist subjects and others relating specifically to women. Enter additional Subject terms as necessary, such as 'politics'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: It is assumed that most workshop scenes are interiors.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Minor deity (male and female) associated with natural features, especially trees. Most commonly encountered in early historic Indian religion. The male (yaksa) is usually depicted as heavily built, while the female (yaksi) is curvaceous and associated with fertility.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a depiction of male and female deities in sexual union.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Individual zodiacal signs are also entered as Associated Names.
